climbs.name: Today is a Good Day to Die

content.description: Climb Moose Head and and before turning the lip follow the crack right to a bolt that protects the face move.
The roof is the crux, moving on smooth rock out and into a layback.
content.location: Climb the Dihedral on the left side of S-Wall next to the Snakeshead.

content.description: About as Traditional as it gets.  About 100' left of S-Wall, from an alcove climb up a crack up to the big face and top out.
content.location: Start 100' left of S-Wall.  Top out, make the jump across and scramble over to the Head Wall anchors and rap.

content.description: According to the old Southern Exposure guidebook, this route is a linkup of the easiest section of the wall. Climb S-Wall to its first bolt, then traverse up/right to the Baptism crack and follow it until you can traverse right to the Bourbon Street belay at the base of the Headwall’s nose. Finish on P2 of Bourbon Street.
content.protection: S-Wall’s first bolt plus cracks. Rack up to #5 Camalots? 0.5 and 0.75 Camalot are key for P2

content.description: A bouldery and vertical variation finish to the classic S-Wall route or Snakes Head Dihedral route. From the vertical crack (anchor) at the top of pitch 2, head left to a V slot in the Snakes Head formation. Solid #2 cam protects the vertical start on good holds as the climbing gets easier once you move up the short 15 foot slot that will take you higher up the the Snakes Head anchor. Rap from Snakes Head or do the jump and head over to the headwall anchors for retreat.
content.protection: #2 or #3 cam high in the crack with a runner for protection.
content.location: From the vertical crack anchor at the top of the 2nd pitch of S-Wall, look up and left to a vertical V slot in the Snakes Head formation. Once you top out, move up and you will be on top of the Snakes Head formation.

content.description: This is one of the best face climbs around.  Climbs up the middle of the wall right and below the Snakes Head.  Climbing up 60 feet of 5.6 to the first bolt, then up to the mid anchor right in the middle of the signature Ess formation.  Then step out and above the Ess (crux) and up, clip another bolt and work the run out 5.8 moves to the top.  You can also link both pitches into one long one.
content.protection: 2 Bolts, 2 Bolt mid anchor, no anchor up top use 1.5" - 1.5" Cams (0.5, 0.75, 1 Camalot will work) or you can belay sitting on the secure horn. Might take some small cams for the upper crack, soothing to the nerves when people above shout to you, that your 40' above that last bolt.
content.location: Look for the Ess formation in the middle of S-Wall.  Up top, scramble up 5.5 moves to the right and over to the rap station off the head wall anchors (155'), watch for cacti on the Bourbon Street Ledge.

content.description:
A route with a fabled history. Chris Rowins aided the crux of the route with a bat hook rating it 5.10 A2, later adding a bolt to replace the hook. 

  Duane Raleigh later freesolo'ed the route upgrading its rating to 5.12 and chopping the aid bolt.
content.location: This route is 100-150 feet to the left of Pizza Face. Just west of where the tree is touching the wall.

content.description: This crack is commonly bouldered but also goes well on gear. The slab is a bit polished down low, but there are great jams to be had. The topout is the crux, there is an easy escape left if you’re feeling spooked.
content.location: The crack starting in a right facing dihedral and a slab on the right side of the crack. in- between Rowins Roof and Pizza Face

content.description: Start ground level, and climb the heavily pocketed face up to one of the heads.  A committing move comes about 20 feet off the deck above some cactus.  Good holds and easy moves above.
content.protection: A big tri-cam works in the lateral crack.
content.location: Climbs from ground level, the west end below the S-Wall proper.

content.description: Starts same as Moosehead, but stays on the lower face and climb up the overlap higher.  Finishes up on Moose's crack.
Climb on big knobs on the face right of the Snakes Head dihedral of S-Wall.  Move up on buckets to a 5.11 face move and into a 5.10 crack to follow out up and onto the face.
content.protection: Cams up to 2.5", small to medium cams for the anchor.
content.location: Start as for Snakes Head Dihedral, escape left or finish up the Snakes Head.

content.description: Climbs the large right facing dihedral and chimney system.  Finish at the ledge, or out on the LSAT/Moose anchor.  A good alternate upper if you did Pizza Face.
content.location: The dihedral just left/west of LSAT.

content.description: Climb past a big hole and up to clip a bolt just below the overhang, to join the upper crack on Moosehead.
content.protection: Bolt, and gear for the crack.
content.location: The face just left/west of Moosehead.

content.description: Climbs the face left/west of Bourbon Street. Takes a direct line to the "amoeba" feature, then angles up over to P2 of Bourbon Street.
content.protection: Gear?  Well, you could clip a bolt or two on BS if your scared.  This route is more like a solo with very sparse gear.
content.location: Just left of BS.  Starting below the BS ledge.

content.description: Climb first pitch of Baptism.  Turn bulge at the anchor (crux) and climb the runout face above.
content.protection: Cams to #4, no anchor, see Baptism

content.description: Climb the first pitch of S-Wall.  The climb the face left of over about 20 feet and clip the last bolt.  Then climb the unprotected face on 5.10 to the top.  Falls have been taken from the top.  I have seen this climbed from the ground up, clipping the only bolt at (90'), skipping S-Walls first pitch, but a fall would be deadly.
Runout and bold climbing, this is a baptism for climbing at Quartz.  Crux is turning the bulge in the 2nd pitch.
content.protection: Stoppers, and cams to up to #4.  No anchor.  #3 and #4 cam for mid anchor.
content.location: Climb the waterstreak  and crack right of S-Wall.

content.description: The formation on the point that lookis like a snakes head.  S-Wall has the unique S rock deposit in the middle of the face.  It can be easy to see from the parking lot.
